awd_titl_txt: Seeding US Africa Cooperation in STEM: A Summer Workshop at Gondar University in Ethiopia
awd_abstract_narration:
The summer workshop on the US Africa Cooperation in STEM is organized by US based academicians and graduate students in partnership with the Ethiopian Physical Society in North America, The University of Akron, Stanford University, and University of Gondar and will take place at the University of Gondar in Ethiopia from June 24?July 1, 2019. It seeks to bring together talented undergraduate and graduate students from major universities across Ethiopia to identify the unique challenges they face as students with limited resources and to help them prepare for highly competitive graduate schools in the US where their potential will be fully developed and have the opportunity to be leading scientists and engineers. The summer workshop will consist of lectures, career panels, and student presentations. The lectures will include current trends in a variety of STEM fields and will mainly focus on soft condensed matter physics. Other STEM fields, such as chemistry, chemical engineering, high energy physics, and cosmology will be also covered in the lectures. This initiative targets the unique need of inspiring African students and also offers US academicians and graduate students a platform to advance their global perspective and expose them to the needs they can address with their research. Informal discussions between the US professors and local professors and researchers will open the opportunity for collaboration going as far as co-advising graduate students. The partial travel support from NSF will mainly be used for supporting US graduate students helping with the organization and execution of the workshop.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant, initiated by U.S.-based graduate students and young faculty, primarily from Africa, aimed to advance STEM education in Ethiopia. The project focused on organizing summer programs, fostering collaborations, and providing research experiences for students. Participation in these summer programs enabled the U.S. conference organizers to establish valuable international collaborations. These efforts have facilitated the recruitment of talented Ethiopian students into graduate programs at various U.S. academic institutions.

The first phase of the summer school took place in Ethiopia from June 24 to July 1, 2019, at two leading institutions: University of Gondar and Addis Ababa Science and Technology University. The program brought together local and international faculty, offering workshops and lectures designed to strengthen STEM education for both undergraduate and graduate students. The curriculum focused on building essential skills in the physical sciences, with the support of Ethiopian and North American faculty, in collaboration with the Ethiopian Physical Society.

Unfortunately, the global COVID-19 pandemic forced the cancellation of the 2020 summer program. Restrictions on travel and health-related concerns made it impossible to carry out in-person events, resulting in a temporary halt to program activities.

In response to the ongoing pandemic, the second phase of the summer school was conducted virtually from August 6-8, 1-2021, in collaboration with the Ethiopian Physical Society in both Ethiopia and North America. Transitioning to an online format allowed the program to continue despite the challenges. Virtual sessions included lectures, discussions, and workshops covering a variety of STEM topics, successfully engaging students from diverse backgrounds.

Building on the success of the previous virtual event, another summer school was held virtually from August 14-18, 2023, further advancing STEM education in Ethiopia through interactive lectures and workshops.


In conclusion, the NSF Frontiers in STEM grant has successfully launched foundational educational and research initiatives in Ethiopia. These programs have established strong collaborations and created pathways for Ethiopian students to pursue advanced STEM education in U.S. institutions. The impact of this grant will continue to benefit STEM education in Ethiopia long after its official conclusion.
